title: Edit the structure of a table in the Content Editor
description:
## Problem to solve

In order to support the full [GitLab Flavored Markdown spec](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/markdown.html#gitlab-flavored-markdown-gfm), the Content Editor must be support rendering and editing all the elements of the standard implementation .

Here, we are focused on editing the structure of a table after it's been added to the Content Editor.

### Intended users

* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Eddie (Content Editor)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#eddie-content-editor)

### User experience goal

The user should be able to add and remove columns or rows individually from the Content Editor. The table should also have an optional header row. 

## Proposal

Provide custom UI controls for a table that enables

- Add a column
- Add a row
- Delete a column
- Delete a row
- Toggle header row


## Details

Extensions to the Content Editor require a few specific details: 

|  |  |
|---|---|
| Input Rule | N/A |
| Paste Rule | [paste_rule] |
| Toolbar Button | [icon] |
| Keyboard Shortcut | [shortcut] |
| Instrumentation | [event_name] |

### Documentation

This feature, as with the content editor itself, is available on both SaaS and Self-managed **Free** tiers

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

We aren't interested in tracking every time a new row is added or removed in the editor, but it would be great to know how often users are making this kind of edit. A counter indicating a monthly active user would probably be sufficient.

epic.title: GitLab Flavored Markdown extensions for Content Editor

title: Edit inline content in a table cell in the Content Editor
description:
## Problem to solve

In order to support the full [GitLab Flavored Markdown spec](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/markdown.html), the Content Editor must be support rendering and editing all the elements of the standard implementation.

Working with tables in Markdown is one of the hardest things in the entire world. No contest. No one should have to do it. If you ask me to update text in a Markdown table that's more than 3x3, I'm just going to recreate it in Google Sheets, make my edits, then run it through a Markdown parser before pasting over the entire table. 

It should be easier to edit content _within_ a table cell and that's what we're focused on here.

### Intended users

* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Eddie (Content Editor)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#eddie-content-editor)

### User experience goal

The user should be able to edit contents of an existing table cell in the Content Editor.

## Proposal

Create an extension for the Content Editor that supports editing text within a table cell.

We're not creating new tables, so there is no toolbar UI necessary. We're not adding rows or columns, so we don't need any contextual UI either. This should be as simple as clicking within a cell and typing. 

## Details

Extensions to the Content Editor require a few specific details: 

|  |  |
|---|---|
| Input Rule | N/A |
| Paste Rule | [paste_rule] |
| Toolbar Button | N/A |
| Keyboard Shortcut | N/A |
| Instrumentation | [event_name] |

### Documentation

* If this feature requires changing permissions, update the permissions document. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html -->

* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

### Available Tier

This feature, as with the content editor itself, is available on both SaaS and Self-managed **Free** tiers

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

As this is just editing text, we probably don't want to track individual instances of editing within a table. Success is just a general sense of relief among anyone asked to edit the contents of a table.

## Problem to solve

In order to support the full [GitLab Flavored Markdown spec](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/markdown.html), the Content Editor must be support rendering and editing all the elements of the standard implementation.

Here, we are focused on rendering tables.

Create an extension for the Content Editor that supports rendering tables.

title: On-demand DAST scan scheduler > Recurring schedules UI & text updates
description:
## Why are we doing this work

This adds the ability to define recurring schedules for on-demand DAST scans. This is based on the work done in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328752.

## Relevant links

* [Epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4876)
* [Designs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225996)
* ~backend counter part issue: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330308


## Non-functional requirements

- [ ] Documentation:
- [ ] Feature flag:
- [ ] Performance:
- [ ] Testing:


## Implementation plan

- [x] In the DAST profiles library.
  - [x] Add a **Schedule** column.
    - [x] Show `-` for non-scheduled scans.
    - [x] Show the repeating option for recurring scans.
      - [x] When hovering the label, a tooltip shows all the details about the schedule (eg `Every month on the 22nd at 9:30 CDT`).
    - [x] Show the scheduled date for one-time scheduled scans.
      - [x] The tooltip provides info about the time: `13:00 CDT`.
  - [-] Change the delete modal's title to `Are you sure you want to delete this scan?`.

title: On-demand DAST scan scheduler > Implement schedules form section
description:
## Why are we doing this work

We're adding a new section to the on-demand scans form to let user define schedules for their scans. In this first ~frontend iteration, we're only adding the bare minimum to trigger a single scheduled scan. In the next iteration, we'll add the ability to setup recurring schedules.

## Relevant links

* [Epic](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4876)
* [Designs](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/225996)
* ~backend counter part issue `TODO: add link when available`


## Non-functional requirements
<!--
Add details for required items and delete others.
-->

- [ ] Documentation:
- [ ] Feature flag:
- [ ] Performance:
- [ ] Testing:


## Implementation plan

- [x] Add the schedules sections.
  - [x] It's a card containing a few fields.
  - [x] A checkbox, unchecked by default, controls whether schedules are enabled or not for the scan.
  - [x] All other fields are disabled as long as the checkbox is unchecked.
  - [x] A dropdown lets users select the timezone for their schedule.
  - [x] A datepicker input to select the date.
  - [x] A timepicker to define the time.
      - We might need to implement a timepicker component as we don't seem to have one at the moment.
  - [x] A **Repeats** dropdown field has the following options:
    - `Every day`
    - `Every week`
    - `Every month`
    - `Every 3 months`
    - `Every 6 months`
    - `Every year`
- [x] User input needs to be persisted to the local storage in case they leave the form and come back to it to finish filling it out.
- [x] When saving the scan, the `dastProfileCreate` mutation is triggered and sends the correct variables to the API.
- [x] When editing a scan, the schedules section needs to be populated with previously stored settings.
- [x] When saving the scan, the `dastProfileUpdate` mutation is triggered and sends the correct variables to the API.

title: Edit code blocks in the Content Editor
description:
## Problem to solve

In order to support the full [CommonMark spec](https://spec.commonmark.org/0.29/), the Content Editor must be support rendering and editing all the elements of the standard implementation .

Here, we are focused on creating blocks of code.

### Intended users

* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Eddie (Content Editor)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#eddie-content-editor)

### User experience goal

The user should be able to create and edit code blocks in the Content Editor.

## Proposal

Create an extension for the Content Editor that supports editing code blocks.

An icon should be displayed in the toolbar. The toolbar icon will create a new code block at the cursor's current position or from any selected text. The toolbar icon should reflect the state of the currently selected span of content. If the content is mixed (for example, the selected characters contain some code block content and some regular text) then we should indicate the inactive state. 

## Details

Extensions to the Content Editor require a few specific details: 

|  |  |
|---|---|
| Input Rule | ``` |
| Paste Rule | [paste_rule] |
| Toolbar Button | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-svgs/blob/main/sprite_icons/doc-code.svg |
| Keyboard Shortcut | [shortcut] |

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

title: OpenAPI fails in runner for API Fuzzing when determining target host
description:
<!-- This template is a great use for issues that are feature::additions or technical tasks for larger issues.-->

### Problem
OpenAPI runner fails when determining target api url. The OpenAPI spec could provide the target url or it could be assembled using the document location along with document content. The OpenAPI data varies among versions (2.0, 3.0.x) and it is optional. Additionally, the runner component should give priority to user configuration for specifying target url provided in env variable or CLI.

[Example failing job](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/benchmark-suite/java-spring-mvn-api-bench/-/jobs/1188795141)

[Example OpenAPI v2 specification that triggers issue](/uploads/bf0b77000a73d743ba43b88c1421085b/openapi.json)

#### Workaround

A user can work around this issue by saving the OpenAPI specification and manually updating it to include a full URL.

### Proposal 
1. [x] Update `GetBaseUrl` so that
   1. [x] First tries to use  input from `ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl`. (It is previously populated with CLI or environment var value) 
   1. [x] For **OpenAPI v3**. It uses the collection `Servers` and tries to find the first valid Url. Remarks:
        1. [x] Server collection is optional, if no server is provided then. It can fall back to input document Uri to get base Url.
        1. [x] [`Server.Url`](https://spec.openapis.org/oas/v3.0.0#server-object) can be relative to the input document Uri.
        1. [x] [`Server.Url`](https://spec.openapis.org/oas/v3.0.0#server-object) can use server variables.
        1. [x] Input document Uri data can be used as a fallback when not enough data to built base Url. This as long as it is an HTTP(S) Uri.
   1. [x] For **OpenApi v2** It should use:  `schemes` collection, `host` node, and `basePath` node. Remarks:
        1. [x] `Schemes` is optional. If not provided, it should use the same as the input document Uri.
        1. [x] `host` is optional. It is name or IP, and optionally port number. If not provided, it should use the same as the input document Uri. It does _not_ support [path templating](https://spec.openapis.org/oas/v2.0#path-templating).
        1. [x]  `basePath` is optional. If provided, must start with '/'. It does _not_ support [path templating](https://spec.openapis.org/oas/v2.0#path-templating).
        1. [x] Input document Uri data can be used as a fallback when not enough data to built base Url. This as long as it is an HTTP(S) Uri.
    1. [x]  Input Uri might not always be an HTTP or HTTPS Uri. If input Uri is not HTTP(s), and not `BaseUrl` have been provided thru `ApplicationOptions`, and it was not possible to compute it based on specification content. Then an error should be thrown
1. [X] Add tests
    1. [X] Tests for different scenarios. 
        1. [X] OpenApiV3 Provide ApplicationBaseUrl (W), input is external uri(X), document uses uri(Y). Expect operation to use Base Uri(W)
        1. [X] OpenApiV3 No ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input is external uri, document does not have servers. Expect: operation use  input Uri 
        1. [X] OpenApiV3 No ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input is local file path, document have Servers using Absolute Uri. Expect: operation to use absolute Uri 
        1. [X] OpenApiV3 No ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input is external uri, document have Servers using relative Uri. Expect operations to use input uri as base Url.
        1. [X] OpenApiV3 No ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input is external uri, document have Servers using relative Uri and using server variables. Expect: operations to use input as base url, and replace variables from server.url
        1. [X] OpenApiV3 No ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input local file path, document does not have Servers. Expected: Expected: Exception because target cannot be computed.
        1. [X] OpenApiV2 Provide ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input is external uri, document has scheme,host. Expected operations to use BaseUrl
        1. [X] OpenApiV2 No ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input is external uri, document does not have host,scheme, or basePath. Expected: operations to use input url
        1. [X] OpenApiV2 No ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input is external uri, document has basePath, but does no have host,scheme. Expected. Use operation to use scheme,host from input uri and attach basePath
        1. [X] OpenApiV2 No ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input is external uri, document has scheme,host,basePath. Expected operations to use document scheme,host,basePath only.
        1. [X] OpenApiV2 No ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input is external uri, document does not have scheme, but has host(with port), basePath. Expected operations to use input uri scheme, and document host and port.
        1. [X] OpenApiV2 No ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input is local file path, document does not have scheme,host,basePath. Expected: Exception because target cannot be computed.
    1. [X] Tests based on reported errors
        1. [X] OpenApiV2 No ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input is external uri, document does not have scheme, host(with port), basePath. Expected operations to use input uri scheme, and document host and port.
        1. [X] OpenApiV2 No ApplicationOptions.BaseUrl, input local file path, document does not have scheme, host(with port), basePath. Expected operations to use http scheme, and document host and port.

### References
* OpenAPI V2.0 Spec https://spec.openapis.org/oas/v2.0
* OpenAPI V3.0 Spec https://spec.openapis.org/oas/v3.0.0

title: Remove references to legacy compliance frameworks
description:
<!-- This template is a great use for issues that are feature::additions or technical tasks for larger issues.-->

### Proposal 

As [noted](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/58884#note_556509300) by @tancnle, despite removing some references to legacy compliance frameworks, some code still exists within the codebase.

I decided to defer removing some of the more tightly coupled and hard-to-remove references to a follow-up issue.

We should remove all references to the hardcoded legacy compliance frameworks (specifically in ComplianceManagement::Framework) and unpick any references to those methods within the test suite.

title: Feature spec for Security Config Page
description:
The Security & Compliance Configuration page is now available for CE and EE Users.

The ability to enable scanners via MR differs between the CE and the EE Versions.

In this MR https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/59001#note_557253398 it was noticed that this differentiation has it tweaks, the bug is fixed but the test-gap remains.

Here's what needs to be tested:

The test must happen in an EE environment. 
We'll need to figure a Security-Scanner which is available for CE and EE Users.
SAST was the first to be available for everybody and I don't see this changing in the near future, so that would be a good pick.

Make sure that on click on "enable via Merge Request" the site does redirect correctly to a new Merge Request page, without any errors. 

If that test passes we ensure that nothing has gone wrong when managing the scanners between the tiers.


### Implementation Plan
- [ ] (add a new test in `ee/spec/features/projects/security/user_views_security_configuration_spec.rb` or a new test file next to it))
- [ ] (load security EE version of security-config page)
- [ ] (select `Configure via Merge Request` Link on SAST)
- [ ] (check if href is correct / click button see if redirect url is correct)

title: FE Research Issue: Give SaaS group owners control over accidental user overages via a `User Cap` setting
description: This issue is meant to break down the Front-End needs of the feature described in https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5803. ## Reference - Designs: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/321934/ - Steps flow for _**Self-Managed User added while User Cap enabled**_ and _**SaaS Member added while User Cap enabled**_: https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5803#note_556204466 - Useful info from the docs about GitLab.com Subscriptions: https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/subscriptions/gitlab_com/ ## Why should we implement this feature in SaaS, but not in Self Managed? At the moment, only Self Managed admins can already control accidental user overages by making use of the option of setting User Caps through the Admin Settings section, like this: This setting is available in **Admin Area > Settings** only for instance admins. This means that this section is not available for .COM admin customers. We need to provide this option to .COM admin customers, but as they lack access to an Admin Settings section, we need to provide them this option elsewhere: at the **Group/Project > Settings** level. ## Initial breakdown 1. [[FE] SaaS - Add Pending Members tab to seat usage page](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333064) 1. [[Docs] SaaS - Document Pending Members tab in seat usage page](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334676) 1. [SaaS - Move "Allow users to request access" setting to a new subsection](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330029) 1. ~~[[UserCap FE]: Add feature flag](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334268)~~ (closed as FF will be implemented in BE issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/332590) 1. [[UserCap FE][Pending members tab]: Add pending approval users](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330027) 1. [[UserCap FE]: Add "User cap" setting to Membership area in group Settings > General](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334296) 1. [[UserCap FE]: Show warning banner when adding users above user cap](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334308) 1. [[UserCap FE][Invited members tab]: Add pending SaaS users to "Invited" members tab](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334288) 1. [[UserCap FE][Invited members tab]: Add a “Pending owner approval” badge for members](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334292) 1. [[UserCap FE][Invited members tab]: Add an “Awaiting user signup” badge for members](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334294) 1. [[UserCap FE][Pending Members tab]: Add "Approve all" button](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334309) 1. [[UserCap FE]: Warn group owners when changing User Cap related settings about automatically approving users ](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/330028) 1. [[UserCap FE][Auto approval modal]: Show exact number of auto approvable members](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334688) 1. [[UserCap][Pending Members tab]: Add confirmation modal for "Approve all" action](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334382) 1. [[UserCap][Pending Members tab]: Add confirmation modal for "Approve" action](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334383) #### Extra notes - setting "Prevent adding new members to project membership within this group" ([design](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/321934/designs/V4.png)) is NOT tied to this issue, even if it appears on the design

title: Make `Service` (integrations) an abstract class
description:
The following discussion from !59635 should be addressed:

- [ ] @arturoherrero started a [discussion](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/59635#note_554946506):  (+3 comments)

    > Using FactoryBoy, we managed to enter an invalid service in the database.
    > ```ruby
    > > build(:service, type: 'JiraService', project: nil, template: true, active: true).valid?
    > => true
    > > build(:jira_service, project: nil, template: true, active: true).valid?
    > => false
    > ```
    > 
    > This is not happening in production because we have different checks:
    > - Frontend validation
    > - Backend validation where we create a `JiraService.new`, not a `Service.new(type: 'JiraService')`. Apart from the `Service` validations, for each specific integration, we have extra validation in the different models: `JiraService`, `JenkinsService`, etc.

title: Inform the user when API's don't return successful status codes
description:
### Problem

Users using API Fuzzing cannot easily tell when the API's being scanned don't return successful error messages in the `record` phase. The `record` phase doesn't perform any fuzzing, it simply calls the API then determines the testing to apply.

An example of this is configuring API Fuzzing with an API that requires authentication. The scan can appear successful even through the APIs are returning 403/402 responses. This makes it hard to understand when a configuration is really working.

[Example customer issue (private slack)](https://gitlab.slack.com/archives/CUTDH1V8R/p1619042850143800)

### Proposal

If an API operation doesn't return a successful status code during the `record` phase of scanning it should be displayed in the job output during testing.

After the testing has completed a summary should be printed in the job output with this information in a digestible format.

Tasks:

1. [x] Add an operation to the scanner that returns the needed information
1. [x] Add a method to the python library to return the information
1. [x] Update worker-entry to display a summary after testing has completed
1. [x] Publish new container

title: Upgrade Content Editor to TipTap v2
description:
## What?

Upgrade TipTap dependency to version v2 beta. 

- [TipTap WebSite](https://www.tiptap.dev/)
- [Upgrade guide](https://www.tiptap.dev/overview/upgrade-guide)

## Why?

- TipTap v2 is a significant improvement over TipTap v1. It has a strong test suite for extensions, it fixes many bugs, and it provides a more consistent and stable API.
- The Content Editor is in early stages and it has a low level of coupling to TipTap v1. These circumstances makes the upgrade cost cheaper than at a later stage. 

## How?

These are the tasks involved in the upgrade based on a Spike I ran today:

- [ ] Add new package dependencies
- [ ] Update Webpack cache group configuration to target the new tiptap dependencies instead of the old ones. 
- [ ] Update the Markdown Serializer to account for the naming changes in several TipTap extensions. 
- [ ] Update the Toolbar Button component to use the new `Editor` class API. 

## Other Notes

- We can’t remove the old tiptap dependencies from the application because they are used by the feature that allows to copy HTML as Markdown in several parts of the application.

title: Insert images in the Content Editor
description:
## Problem to solve

In order to support the full [CommonMark spec](https://spec.commonmark.org/0.29/), the Content Editor must be support rendering and editing all the elements of the standard implementation .

Here, we are focused on inserting or uploading images.

### Intended users

* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Eddie (Content Editor)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#eddie-content-editor)

### User experience goal

The user should be able to insert and upload images in the Content Editor.

## Proposal

Create an extension for the Content Editor that supports inserting a new image.

- An icon should be displayed in the toolbar. The toolbar icon will display custom UI that allows you to reference an existing image URL manually or upload a new image. 
- Dragging an image into the content editor should upload that image and insert it at the cursor's current position
- An image should be able to be pasted from the clipboard

## Details

Extensions to the Content Editor require a few specific details: 

|  |  |
|---|---|
| Input Rule | N/A |
| Paste Rule | [paste_rule] |
| Toolbar Button | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-svgs/blob/main/sprite_icons/doc-image.svg |
| Keyboard Shortcut | [shortcut] |
| Instrumentation | [event_name] |

### Documentation

title: Create and edit links in the Content Editor
description:
## Problem to solve

In order to support the full [CommonMark spec](https://spec.commonmark.org/0.29/), the Content Editor must be support rendering and editing all the elements of the standard implementation .

Here, we are focused on creating text links.

### Intended users

* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Eddie (Content Editor)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#eddie-content-editor)

### User experience goal

The user should be able to create and edit links in the Content Editor.

## Proposal

Create an extension for the Content Editor that supports editing links.

- An icon should be displayed in the toolbar. The toolbar icon will create a link at the current cursor's position. 
- Any selected text will be used as the display text
- The toolbar icond should reflect the state of the currently selected span of content. If the content is mixed (for example, the selected characters contain a link and some regular text) then we should indicate the inactive state. 
- Custom UI will allow for the link's `URL` and `display text` to be defined or edited. 
- Any plain URL that's pasted into the editor that is not surrounded by backticks should automatically become a link using the URL as the display text.

## Details

Extensions to the Content Editor require a few specific details: 

|  |  |
|---|---|
| Input Rule | `[display text](url)` or `http://website.com`|
| Paste Rule | [paste_rule] |
| Toolbar Button | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-svgs/blob/main/sprite_icons/link.svg |
| Keyboard Shortcut | `CMD/CTRL + K` |
| Instrumentation | [event_name] |

* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)

* [Eddie (Content Editor)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#eddie-content-editor)

### User experience goal

The user should be able to create and edit Headers 1-6 in the Content Editor.

## Proposal

Create an extension for the Content Editor that supports editing headers.

An icon should be displayed in the toolbar. The toolbar icon will contain a dropdown that allows you to select the header level. The current header level should be reflected in the state of the icon when a span of content is selected. If the content is mixed (for example, the selected characters contain some bold and some regular text) then we should indicate the inactive state. 

## Details

Extensions to the Content Editor require a few specific details: 

|  |  |
|---|---|
| Input Rule | `#`, `##`, `###`, `#####`, `#####`, `######`  |
| Paste Rule | [paste_rule] |
| Toolbar Button | [icon] |
| Keyboard Shortcut | TBD |
| Instrumentation | [event_name] |

### Documentation

<!-- See the Feature Change Documentation Workflow https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/workflow.html#for-a-product-change

* Add all known Documentation Requirements in this section. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/documentation/workflow.html
* If this feature requires changing permissions, update the permissions document. See https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/permissions.html -->

### Availability & Testing

<!-- This section needs to be retained and filled in during the workflow planning breakdown phase of this feature proposal, if not earlier.

* Unit test changes
* Integration test changes
* End-to-end test change

See the test engineering planning process and reach out to your counterpart Software Engineer in Test for assistance: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/quality/test-engineering/#test-planning -->

### Available Tier

This feature, as with the rich text editor itself, is available on both SaaS and Self-managed **Free** tiers

### What does success look like, and how can we measure that?

An event should be added to track creation of a new header node through the UI. We aren't interested in tracking every instance of headers in existing content, but it would be great to know how often this extension is invoked through the editor, and whether it is done by using the toolbar, keyboard shortcut, or by typing directly into the editor. 

It would also be nice to know if someone changes the header level from the UI, using the keyboard shortcut, or by typing into the editor.

title: Fix `Verify SAML Configuration` button in SAML settings
description:
### Summary

The `Verify SAML Configuration` button in "Group" -> "Settings" -> "SAML SSO" has two issues:

1. The tooltip does not display the correct message. It always displays `Group SAML must be enabled to test`
1. The button can be clicked even when it is disabled

### Steps to reproduce

1. Setup SAML in GDK: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab-development-kit/-/blob/main/doc/howto/saml.md
1. Navigate to "Group" -> "Settings" -> "SAML SSO" and setup a SAML provider
1. Uncheck the `Toggle SAML authentication` checkbox

### Example Project

<!-- If possible, please create an example project here on GitLab.com that exhibits the problematic 
behavior, and link to it here in the bug report. If you are using an older version of GitLab, this 
will also determine whether the bug is fixed in a more recent version. -->

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

1. The tooltip does not display the correct message. It always displays `Group SAML must be enabled to test`
1. The button can be clicked even when it is disabled

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

1. The tooltip should display a message saying why it is disabled
1. The button should not be clickable when disabled

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

![Screen_Shot_2021-04-21_at_12.45.43_PM](/uploads/8bfeddb99f5632abb8389c01c8feb91f/Screen_Shot_2021-04-21_at_12.45.43_PM.png)

### Possible fixes

1. The [`this.samlProviderEnabled`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/saml_providers/saml_settings_form.js#L107) doesn't actually exist and is causing issues with the tooltip.
1. There isn't a great way to disable an anchor tag. We will need to have two buttons. One that is a disabled `button` tag and the other that is the anchor tag. We will hide/show show these buttons depending on the state.

title: Document logic behind SM user counts which affect billing
description:
## Summary

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/growth/product/-/issues/1445, I documented how Max User count was being calculated, however, since that issue was created over a year ago, some changes have occurred.

In this issue, we will research various user counts within the self-managed instance which affect subscription billing. Through this research we will clearly define how the Max User count is being calculated, exception cases and variations on the calculation based on version. This information will be added to our [subscription docs page](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/subscriptions/self_managed/) as reference for the community.

## Scoped fields

title: Write time-decay architectural blueprint for CI/CD data
description:
<!-- Instructions: Use this template for a proof of concept or when a deeper technical evaluation is required. Please weigh tech evaluation issues and follow the instructions below accordingly. --> 

### Topic to Evaluate

In https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/www-gitlab-com/-/merge_requests/79193, the [Database Scalability](https://about.gitlab.com/company/team/structure/working-groups/database-scalability/) Team has begun work on a partitioning strategy called Time Decay. 

We would like to be able to take advantage of this strategy in ~"group::pipeline execution"  for the more data-intensive areas, and specifically look at how we can partition `ci_builds` by leveraging the time decay pattern.

### Expectations of the spike

<!-- Outline the tasks with issues that you need to evaluate as a part of the implementation issue -->

- [x] Read up on the ongoing CI/CD data modelling proposals from: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/architecture/tasks/-/issues/5
- [x] Write up a proposal for sharding `ci_builds` by time decay (blueprint?)  OR if we want to [Enable removal of data per Archive of old builds](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-com/gl-infra/infrastructure/-/issues/5588)

title: Enable secure bot authorization workflows with CI_JOB_TOKEN
description:
<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
*This page may contain information related to upcoming products, features and functionality.
It is important to note that the information presented is for informational purposes only, so please do not rely on the information for purchasing or planning purposes.
Just like with all projects, the items mentioned on the page are subject to change or delay, and the development, release, and timing of any products, features, or functionality remain at the sole discretion of GitLab Inc.*
<!-- triage-serverless v3 PLEASE DO NOT REMOVE THIS SECTION -->
<!-- The first section "Release notes" is required if you want to have your release post blog MR auto generated. Currently in BETA, details on the **release post item generator** can be found in the handbook:  https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/blog/release-posts/#release-post-item-generator and this video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rfn9ebgTwKg. The next four sections: "Problem to solve", "Intended users", "User experience goal", and "Proposal", are strongly recommended in your first draft, while the rest of the sections can be filled out during the problem validation or breakdown phase. However, keep in mind that providing complete and relevant information early helps our product team validate the problem and start working on a solution. -->

### Release notes

<!-- What is the problem and solution you're proposing? This content sets the overall vision for the feature and serves as the release notes that will populate in various places, including the [release post blog](https://about.gitlab.com/releases/categories/releases/) and [Gitlab project releases](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/releases). " -->

The CI_JOB_TOKEN CI/CD variable makes API calls more intuitive within CI/CD jobs, enabling advanced automation. For example, the token can be used with bot automation projects that run pipelines in other projects. The token is short-lived, but in an effort to make its usage even more secure we are adding a setting that lets you list the exact projects that can be accessed with your project's CI job token. If the token is used to try to access other projects, it will be denied access to the API. In the bot automation example, it gives you additional control over the exact projects your bot will have access to and an added layer of security when using the CI_JOB_TOKEN CI/CD variable. This setting is enabled by default for all new projects, and we strongly recommend enabling it in all your existing projects.  

### Problem to solve  

I need a secure way to enable a customer to authorize a bot to do work on their behalf without compromising all customers who use the bot. Many users leverage the CI_JOB_TOKEN to do this, although when a bot uses a ci_token to do things like auto-remediation (make an mr, merge it) it is able to leak/be compromised in such a way that one customer can maliciously grab information it leaks and then use the to get any other customer (who has authorized the bot) repo/code.


### Intended users

<!-- Who will use this feature? If known, include any of the following: types of users (e.g. Developer), personas, or specific company roles (e.g. Release Manager). It's okay to write "Unknown" and fill this field in later.

Personas are described at https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/

* [Cameron (Compliance Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#cameron-compliance-manager)
* [Parker (Product Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#parker-product-manager)
* [Delaney (Development Team Lead)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#delaney-development-team-lead)
* [Presley (Product Designer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#presley-product-designer)
* [Sasha (Software Developer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sasha-software-developer)
* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Sidney (Systems Administrator)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sidney-systems-administrator)
* [Sam (Security Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#sam-security-analyst)
* [Rachel (Release Manager)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#rachel-release-manager)
* [Alex (Security Operations Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#alex-security-operations-engineer)
* [Simone (Software Engineer in Test)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#simone-software-engineer-in-test)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops)
* [Priyanka (Platform Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#priyanka-platform-engineer)
* [Dana (Data Analyst)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#dana-data-analyst)
* [Eddie (Content Editor)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#eddie-content-editor)
-->

* [Alex (Security Operations Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#alex-security-operations-engineer)

### User experience goal

<!-- What is the single user experience workflow this problem addresses?
For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ -->

Bots should be able to use the CI_JOB_TOKEN without fear of leaking data or information.

### Proposal 

Introduce a mechanism (when enabled via project settings) that limits the use of CI_JOB_TOKEN to the project where it originated from. By default, with this setting on, the CI_JOB_TOKEN won't be used outside the project's scope. However, project maintainers/owners can add other projects to the CI_JOB_TOKEN scope. This way the token can be used across a list of selected projects. For example, to trigger multi-project pipelines

Introduce a section `Token access` in the projects settings where owners/maintainers can:

* Introduce a setting toggle to limit job token access(a more secure behaviour)
* To avoid breaking anything, this option will come unchecked for all existing projects
* For new projects this setting should come checked so limiting access for job tokens(initially being limited to the native project) becomes the default behaviour
* Users are allowed to add/remove projects for the CI_JOB_TOKEN scope

| Design Proposal |
| -------|
| ![Screen_Shot_2021-05-10_at_1.23.52_PM](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/uploads/bf32d70c868e64c7c987befdcd12ca8c/Screen_Shot_2021-05-10_at_1.23.52_PM.png) |

### Permissions and Security
Following roles have access to the setting 

* [ ] Guest (10) members
* [ ] Reporter (20) members
* [ ] Developer (30) members
* [x] Maintainer (40) members
* [x] Owner (50) members

title: Implement basic rebalancing
description:
### Problem to solve

When using several database servers containing many logical databases, it may be desirable to rebalance individual logical databases. Rebalancing means moving those to another server.

1. Noise (lots of activity)
1. Tenant isolation

### Proposal 

Implement minimal rebalancing. Ultimately this should be an operation that can be performed without downtime. First implementation may still require downtime.

## Solution

title: Investigate: Load balancer behavior
description:
## Problem to solve

Should the sharding middleware be aware of the GitLab [Database Load Balancer](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/administration/database_load_balancing.html) ?

Do we still need read-replicas for shards ?

## Solution

title: Sharding query analysis
description:
Sharding describes a way to split and distribute a data model. Similarly, partitioning only splits but doesnt distribute data.

The common problem is using the right split dimension for your application. There is a few questions associated with that:

1. What is the "right" dimension to slice by?
1. How do we validate a chosen dimension is the right one?
1. How do we understand which parts of the application work nicely with a given split, and which parts wont?

This issue explains how we might approach answering these questions, in particular (3).

### Data access patterns

The inherent problem partitioning/sharding solves is to improve data access. By choosing a certain split dimension, we optimize for accessing data by this dimension. At the same time, we typically need to expect data access that doesn't follow this dimension to significantly degrade - it's a good working assumption to think of this as "unfeasible", since queries would go across shards.

What is a data access pattern?

We access data, database tables, with certain filter criteria. For example, we might be looking at the `issues` table and we're interested in issues for a certain project:

```sql
SELECT * FROM issue WHERE project_id = ? 
```

The `project_id = ?` is a way to define an access pattern. It's "lookup by project". Similarily, we can have "lookup by user" with `WHERE author_id = ?` or similar.

Slicing a data model (aka partitioning or sharding) picks a certain access pattern to optimize for. This is then called the "sharding key". Database queries, that have the sharding key as a filter - i.e. matching the data access pattern - benefit tremendously from the sharding approach. Other's - without the sharding key and hence a different access pattern - they don't.

For GitLab, we're basically interested in answering:

Given a sharding key, e.g. top-level namespaces, 

1. what queries can we expect to be GOOD, i.e. have a matching data access pattern
1. what queries do we need to expect to be bad, i.e. use an incompatible access pattern

### Making incompatible data access patterns compatible

We pick the top-level namespace as the sharding key now.

Let's assume we have this query:

```sql
SELECT * FROM issue WHERE project_id = ? 
```

Upon first sight, this qualifies as BAD - it doesn't have the sharding key. 

However, on second sight, we realize that we can easily infer the sharding key in our data model. That is because an issue is always associated with a project, which in turn is associated with a namespace and ultimately a top-level namespaces.

In this transitive nature, we can infer the sharding key for many queries and thereby move them into a GOOD state.

### Query analysis on .com

Ideally, we don't have BAD queries. We know that's not going to be the case though. In order to understand which parts are going to be problematic for us, we can do the following:

On GitLab.com, we keep track of the N most frequent queries we execute in a normalized fashion in `pg_stat_statements`. At any time, this allows us to retrieve a portion of queries we typically execute.

We can parse these queries (using `pg_query` gem or similar) to understand their structure.

If certain filters like `namespace_id = ?` are present, we can mark the query as GOOD. 

Next, we define a set of rules to reason about the transitive nature of data access patterns we described above. For  example, we can always mark a query as good if we have `project_id = ?` or `issues.id = ?` or `pipelines.id = ?` etc. This allows us to mark a large portion of - otherwise problematic - queries as GOOD.

The remaining part is BAD queries we need to be able to deal with if we pick this sharding key.

This is likely not an exact science - we might overlook some queries. We can see how many BAD queries are left after this analysis though and work on either finding solutions how to make them compatible or actually mark them BAD.

### Is this actionable?

I believe this is actionable right now on GitLab.com without actually changing anything in the data model. We can use the workload from `pg_stat_statements` and perform this as an offline analysis.

An alternative approach would be to instrument the ActiveRecord models in a way that allows to reason about the same issue. I haven't worked out the specifics here yet, but if we find a way here, we can even track those metrics (how many GOOD/BAD queries we have) in Prometheus.

title: Rails 6.1 deprecation warnings
description:
Rails 6.1 introduces breaking changes: https://edgeguides.rubyonrails.org/6_1_release_notes.html and some of them are warned about currently:

- [ ] DEPRECATION WARNING: Accessing hashes returned from config_for by non-symbol keys is deprecated and will be removed in Rails 6.1. Use symbols for access instead.
- [x] DEPRECATION WARNING: ActiveSupport::Multibyte::Chars#normalize is deprecated and will be removed from Rails 6.1. Use #unicode_normalize(:nfkd) instead.
- [x] DEPRECATION WARNING: ActiveSupport::Multibyte::Unicode#normalize is deprecated and will be removed from Rails 6.1. Use String#unicode_normalize(:nfc) instead. (called from safe_title at /Users/tkuah/code/ee-gdk/gitlab/app/models/milestone.rb:265)
- [x] DEPRECATION WARNING: ActiveSupport::Multibyte::Unicode#downcase is deprecated and will be removed from Rails 6.1. Use String methods directly.
- [x] DEPRECATION WARNING: Dangerous query method (method whose arguments are used as raw SQL) called with non-attribute argument(s): "COUNT(*) DESC". Non-attribute arguments will be disallowed in Rails 6.1. This method should not be called with user-provided values, such as request parameters or model attributes. Known-safe values can be passed by wrapping them in Arel.sql().

A separate group of warnings related to default scoping:

- [x] DEPRECATION WARNING: Class level methods will no longer inherit scoping from `deployed_to_cluster` in Rails 6.1. To continue using the scoped relation, pass it into the block directly. To instead access the full set of models, as Rails 6.1 will, use `Environment.default_scoped`.
- [x] DEPRECATION WARNING: Class level methods will no longer inherit scoping from `create` in Rails 6.1. To continue using the scoped relation, pass it into the block directly. To instead access the full set of models, as Rails 6.1 will, use `DesignManagement::Design.default_scoped`.'
- [x] DEPRECATION WARNING: Class level methods will no longer inherit scoping from `distinct_on_user_with_max_access_level` in Rails 6.1. To continue using the scoped relation, pass it into the block directly. To instead access the full set of models, as Rails 6.1 will, use `Member.default_scoped`.
- [x] DEPRECATION WARNING: Class level methods will no longer inherit scoping from `create!` in Rails 6.1. To continue using the scoped relation, pass it into the block directly. To instead access the full set of models, as Rails 6.1 will, use `Packages::Package.default_scoped`.
- [x] DEPRECATION WARNING: Class level methods will no longer inherit scoping from `outside_pipeline_family` in Rails 6.1. To continue using the scoped relation, pass it into the block directly. To instead access the full set of models, as Rails 6.1 will, use `Ci::Pipeline.default_scoped`.
- [x] DEPRECATION WARNING: Class level methods will no longer inherit scoping from `with_unique_issue_ids` in Rails 6.1. To continue using the scoped relation, pass it into the block directly. To instead access the full set of models, as Rails 6.1 will, use `BackfillVersionAuthorAndCreatedAt::Version.default_scoped`.

Grepping the [deprecations.zip](/uploads/4bcaba3d28ce9fa9903a9a21fae60e2a/deprecations.zip) may help to find a test that reproduces a warning, but please note that the warnings are represented as a multiline string. For example, the one about default scopes looks like the following in the file:

```
- 'DEPRECATION WARNING: Class level methods will no longer inherit scoping from `deployed_to_cluster`
  in Rails 6.1. To continue using the scoped relation, pass it into the block directly.
  To instead access the full set of models, as Rails 6.1 will, use `Environment.default_scoped`.'
```

title: Investigate : Rails 6.0 and Rails 6.1 native database sharding
description:
Investigate how GitLab works with Rails 6.0 and Rails 6.1 native database sharding.

See https://guides.rubyonrails.org/active_record_multiple_databases.html 

/cc @fzimmer

## Goals

1. Add multiple databases
1. Create new shard with top-level namespace
1. Show a group from new shard
1. Create a new sub-group in new shard
1. Show a group's members
1. ~~Create new project in new shard~~
1. ~~Run a pipeline~~
1. Investigate dynamically add new databases
1. Report back

## Findings

Summary: Rails 6.1 is viable to be used for the horizontal sharding POC

1. I was able to run migrations in a shard, show the group page for a group, create a sub-group and show the group page for a sub-group.
1. It is possible to create multiple DB with a static configuration
1. There are some hints that may help with creating a dynamic `config/database.yml` in https://github.com/rails/rails/pull/36560
1. We can run migrations for each DB, see `bin/rails -T`, after you setup multiple DBs. `rails db:migrate` migrates DB migrations for all databases, which is nice.
1. The main mechanism is setting up `connects_to(shard: ...)` on each model. You then use `connected_to(role: :reading, shard: :shard_one) { query }` to run a query. Note the `role` is required. While using `connected_to`, non sharded models are not affected, eg.

    ```
    gitlabhq_development=# select count(1) from users;
     count 
    -------
        98
    gitlabhq_development_shard_one=# select count(1) from users;
     count 
    -------
         1
    gitlabhq_development=# select count(1) from namespaces;
     count 
    -------
       107
    gitlabhq_development_shard_one=# select count(1) from namespaces;
     count 
    -------
        10
    
    [2] pry(main)> NamespaceShard.connected_to(role: :reading, shard: :shard_one) { puts Namespace.count; puts User.count }
       (10.4ms)  SELECT COUNT(*) FROM "namespaces" /*application:console,line:(pry):2:in `block in <main>'*/
    10
       (2.1ms)  SELECT COUNT(*) FROM "users" /*application:console,line:(pry):2:in `block in <main>'*/
    98
    ```

1. ~~More research is needed on how to setup `connects_to(shard: ...)` with dynamic shards.~~
1. Rails Associations are not smart enough to know about shards. Here it's getting confused with the routes association.

    ```
    # Good
    [8] pry(main)> Group.with_route.sharded_find 2
      Group Load (2.5ms)  SELECT "namespaces".* FROM "namespaces" WHERE "namespaces"."type" = 'Group' AND "namespaces"."id" = 2 LIMIT 1 /*application:console,line:/app/models/namespace.rb:138:in `block in get'*/
      Route Load (0.6ms)  SELECT "routes".* FROM "routes" WHERE "routes"."source_type" = 'Namespace' AND "routes"."source_id" = 2 /*application:console,line:/app/models/namespace.rb:138:in `block in get'*/
    => #<Group id:2 @lost-and-found>
    
    # Bad, the only mitigation is to ensure unique IDs across shards
    [9] pry(main)> Group.sharded_find 2
      Group Load (0.6ms)  SELECT "namespaces".* FROM "namespaces" WHERE "namespaces"."type" = 'Group' AND "namespaces"."id" = 2 LIMIT 1 /*application:console,line:/app/models/namespace.rb:138:in `block in get'*/
      Route Load (1.0ms)  SELECT "routes".* FROM "routes" WHERE "routes"."source_id" = 2 AND "routes"."source_type" = 'Namespace' LIMIT 1 /*application:console,line:/app/models/concerns/routable.rb:103:in `full_path'*/
    => #<Group id:2 @bethany_mccullough>
    ```

1. Same problem but with parent association

    ```
     Group.new(parent_id: 2).parent.path
      Namespace Load (0.7ms)  SELECT "namespaces".* FROM "namespaces" WHERE "namespaces"."id" = 2 LIMIT 1 /*application:console,line:(pry):12:in `<main>'*/
    => "bethany_mccullough"
    ```

1. The Rails logs does not really show which _shard_ a query is executed on. Potential ~Observability improvement here, to annotate with `ActiveRecord::Base.current_shard`
1. `while_preventing_writes` (https://github.com/rails/rails/blob/8b83793549fed994bf0231aff444aa74648b3c35/activerecord/lib/active_record/connection_handling.rb#L219) and also the `prevent_writes:` option looks useful too.
1. See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/60088 for more detailed notes, and POC code
1. I was able to dynamically construct a shard aware model using `ActiveRecord::Base.configurations.configs_for(env_name: Rails.env)`. This seems to work with 2 DBs (three tier), 1 'primary' DB (three tier), and 1 DB (two tier).
1. This means if for any reason a record was created in a shard, but the shard was withdrawn from configuration, we will see errors like `No connection pool for 'NamespaceShard' found for the 'shard_one' shard.`. Much like Gitaly shards.

### Due date

Estimate 2021-04-30, confidence: 50%

title: Geo: Investigate unhandled uploaders
description:
For each of these uploaders, determine if we need to open an issue to replicate it with Geo:

          DeletedObjectUploader,
          DependencyProxy::FileUploader,
          Packages::Composer::CacheUploader,
          Packages::Debian::ComponentFileUploader,
          Packages::Debian::DistributionReleaseFileUploader,
          Pages::DeploymentUploader

These were surfaced in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/59798/diffs#note_556327961.

## Results

* `DeletedObjectUploader`: Used by `Ci::DeletedObject`. I believe we don't want to replicate this since I believe the files are physically the same files referenced by `Ci::JobArtifact`.
* `DependencyProxy::FileUploader`: We do want to replicate this, and here is the issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/259694
* `Pages::DeploymentUploader`: We do want to replicate this, and here is the epic https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/589
* `Packages::Debian::ComponentFileUploader`: We do want to replicated this, and here is the issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333611. Note that this feature is not yet released.
* `Packages::Debian::DistributionReleaseFileUploader`: We do want to replicated this, and here is the issue https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/333615. Note that this feature is not yet released.
* `Packages::Composer::CacheUploader`: Might not be needed https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328491#note_600822092

title: Evaluation: declare shardability of each model
description:
## Goal

1. Encourage each group to own the shard-ability of their data model(s)
1. Surface which features potentially need re-work to be shardable

## Idea

Taking a leaf from `feature_category:` in Controllers and API endpoints, we should have a `shardable_by:` key in each model.

```
shardable_by: { type: :namespace, association: :group }
```

Where `type` can be `:namespace`, or `:project` in the future; and `association` must be a valid `belongs_to:` association for that model.

title: Make it clearer that another issue tracker is enabled
description:
## Problem Currently, it's not clear that only one issue tracker integration can be enabled at once. There are some cases where it is possible to enable multiple trackers at once which results in errors and the [inability to disable them correctly](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328456). ## Proposal - When an integration issue tracker is enable, display a non-dismissable alert on all other issue tracker integration configuration views. Alert UI text: > **Another issue tracker is already in use**
>Only one issue tracker service can be active at a time. Please disable the active tracker first and try again. | Current | Proposal | | ------ | ------ | | ![current](/uploads/9666ff559d7aaa9f3054538a3c0ed301/current.png) | ![proposal](/uploads/c40e44cf3762489b769937ac40e49f7f/proposal.png) |

### Summary

The license of my [project](https://gitlab.com/steelman1/freecad-electrical-workbench) is not properly recognized. The [LICENSE](https://gitlab.com/steelman1/freecad-electrical-workbench/-/blob/ccb6703e9b5f4f760f257a4c9c92472df45aac0e/LICENSE) file contains LGPL2 downloaded from FSF but the label next to the scales icon says "Other"

### Steps to reproduce

1. Create a project
2. Commit LGPL2 (not 2.1) text as LICENSE

### Example Project

[FreeCAD Electrical Workbench](https://gitlab.com/steelman1/freecad-electrical-workbench)

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

License recognized as Other.
<!-- Describe what actually happens. -->

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

License recognized as _GNU LGPLv2.0_

title: Fix flaky test for NuGet lock file parser in Gemnasium
description:
<!---
Please read this!

Before opening a new issue, make sure to search for keywords in the issues
filtered by the "regression" or "bug" label:

- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=regression
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/issues?label_name%5B%5D=bug

and verify the issue you're about to submit isn't a duplicate.
--->

### Summary

Unit test `TestNuget/Parse/duplicates/dependencies` is flaky, making the pipeline of the [gemnasium](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium) project fail from time to time.

This is might not be a user-facing bug but contributors to the `gemnasium` project have to trigger a new pipeline when the `go test` job fail. That's a waste of time, and when deploying a new release of `gemnasium` this makes for extra context switching between issue page, MR page, and pipeline view, until the pipeline succeeds.

### Further details

The unit test fails at [scanner/parser/nuget/nuget_test.go#L80](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.29.5/scanner/parser/nuget/nuget_test.go#L80) when comparing the dependencies extracted from [./fixtures/duplicates/packages.lock.json](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.29.6/scanner/parser/nuget/fixtures/duplicates/packages.lock.json) to the ones recorded in [./duplicates/dependencies.json](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.29.6/scanner/parser/nuget/expect/duplicates/dependencies.json).

Here's an excerpt of the `package.lock.json`:

```json
{
  "version": 1,
  "dependencies": {
    ".NETCoreApp,Version=v5.0": {
      "jive": {
        "type": "Direct",
        "requested": "[0.2.0, )",
        "resolved": "0.1.0"
      },
      "Microsoft.ChakraCore": {
        "type": "Direct",
        "requested": "[1.12, )",
        "resolved": "1.12"
      }
    },
    ".NETCoreApp,Version=v3.0": {
      "jive": {
        "type": "Direct",
        "requested": "[0.1.0, )",
        "resolved": "0.1.0",
        "contentHash": "oPBGSgY7X2/CMnWGDVdCIDnvaQGXfZz+hnC2PmvjStqDz72ZwNbkPqXYo47QyGOfLYdsp1aieP+Km2KyZMDUSg=="
      },
      "Microsoft.ChakraCore": {
        "type": "Direct",
        "requested": "[1.11.18, )",
        "resolved": "1.11.18",
        "contentHash": "jPtaoN8ZaRcioMvl2aUMiqhmKVMxYYyR0UCCsQ1viKC9qoiqZGWtXufdOAm1U/IzULAtDmVBTdsSdDyt4ND81A=="
      }
  }
}
```

(This fixture might be updated in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/merge_requests/197.)

Currently the parser either selects version `1.12` or version `1.11.18` of `Microsoft.ChakraCore` as a top-level dependency because it resolves dependency names to package names and versions using a map, and this map is built when iterating the "targets" and their dependencies in a non-deterministic way.

Links
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.29.6/scanner/parser/nuget/nuget.go#L75
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.29.6/scanner/parser/nuget/nuget.go#L86
- https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/blob/v2.29.6/scanner/parser/nuget/nuget.go#L95

NOTE: This only affects the `dependencies` return by the NuGet parser, not the `packages`.

### Steps to reproduce

Trigger pipelines for the [gemnasium](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium) project until the `go test` job fails.

### What is the current *bug* behavior?

`go test` job fails because `TestNuget/Parse/duplicates/dependencies` fails because it either returns `Microsoft.ChakraCore` 1.11.18 or 1.12 as a top-level, when processing the `duplicates` fixtures

### What is the expected *correct* behavior?

`go test` always succeeds, and the NuGet lock file parser always returns both `Microsoft.ChakraCore` 1.11.18 and 1.12 as top-level dependencies

### Relevant logs and/or screenshots

https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium/-/jobs/1303773084

```
=== RUN   TestNuget/Parse/duplicates/dependencies
    nuget_test.go:54: 
        	Error Trace:	nuget_test.go:54
        	Error:      	elements differ
        	            	
        	            	extra elements in list A:
        	            	([]interface {}) (len=2) {
        	            	 (parser.Dependency) {
        	            	  From: (*parser.Package)(<nil>),
        	            	  To: (*parser.Package)({
        	            	   Name: (string) (len=20) "Microsoft.ChakraCore",
        	            	   Version: (string) (len=7) "1.11.18"
        	            	  }),
        	            	  VersionRange: (string) (len=11) "[1.11.18, )",
        	            	  Dev: (bool) false
        	            	 },
        	            	 (parser.Dependency) {
        	            	  From: (*parser.Package)(<nil>),
        	            	  To: (*parser.Package)({
        	            	   Name: (string) (len=20) "Microsoft.ChakraCore",
        	            	   Version: (string) (len=7) "1.11.18"
        	            	  }),
        	            	  VersionRange: (string) (len=8) "[1.12, )",
        	            	  Dev: (bool) false
        	            	 }
        	            	}
        	            	
        	            	
        	            	extra elements in list B:
        	            	([]interface {}) (len=2) {
        	            	 (parser.Dependency) {
        	            	  From: (*parser.Package)(<nil>),
        	            	  To: (*parser.Package)({
        	            	   Name: (string) (len=20) "Microsoft.ChakraCore",
        	            	   Version: (string) (len=4) "1.12"
        	            	  }),
        	            	  VersionRange: (string) (len=11) "[1.11.18, )",
        	            	  Dev: (bool) false
        	            	 },
        	            	 (parser.Dependency) {
        	            	  From: (*parser.Package)(<nil>),
        	            	  To: (*parser.Package)({
        	            	   Name: (string) (len=20) "Microsoft.ChakraCore",
        	            	   Version: (string) (len=4) "1.12"
        	            	  }),
        	            	  VersionRange: (string) (len=8) "[1.12, )",
        	            	  Dev: (bool) false
        	            	 }
        	            	}
        	            	
```

Full log: [issue-328451-job.log](/uploads/21e5a3ae8d339efdbc6f2b5b8b970c9c/issue-328451-job.log)

### Possible fixes

- workaround: change the way the NuGet lock file parser build the `dependencies`, and make it deterministic when processing a lock file that has multiple targets with similar or identical packages
- workaround: only keep 1 target defined in the lock file, and ignore others; this ensures data consistent and simplify the implementation, but vulnerabilities might not be reported if the target being scanned isn't the one used in production
- workaround: generate 1 dependency graph per target, and merge them before returning `packages` and `dependencies`; merging dependency graphs isn't trivial though because they might end sharing the very same node, because of the way duplicates are removed from the returned `packages`
- true fix: return 1 dependency graph per target; this is a large change impacting everything from the analyzer to the report format to the GitLab backend and frontend

title: Temporary container for 3.9 python
description:
### IMPORTANT NOTE

You can use this container by replacing the `image` `name` in your configuration yml

```
gemnasium-python-dependency_scanning:
  image:
    name: registry.gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python:2-python-3.9
```

However this is a temporary work around, we will announce [deprecation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334060) - and [removal](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/334061) will be swiftly after (as short as 1 release)

YOU MUST KEEP A WATCH ON THE DEPRECATION ISSUE OR THE IMAGE MAY GO AWAY WITHOUT YOU BEING PREPARED

### Problem to solve 

<!-- What problem do we solve? Try to define the who/what/why of the opportunity as a user story. For example, "As a (who), I want (what), so I can (why/value)." -->

There are users of python 3.7 and 3.9 who can not use dependency scanning today - and can not wait for the long term solution.

### User experience goal

For example, "The user should be able to use the UI/API/.gitlab-ci.yml with GitLab to <perform a specific task>"
https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/ux/ux-research-training/user-story-mapping/ -->

Follow instructions and then be able to use dependency scanning temporarily

### Proposal

<!-- How are we going to solve the problem? Try to include the user journey! https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/journeys/#user-journey -->

Create a one off image using 3.9 (and have a 3.7 user test if it resolves their issue) clearly indicate it is a temporary fix and have it named and tagged as such. All people using it should be collected in an issue (a private one?) to be informed when the correct feature is released.

### Implementation plan

1. change the [Dockerfile](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/-/blob/v2.18.1/Dockerfile#L13) so that the version referenced in the base image becomes a Docker build argument named `PYTHON_VERSION`

   See [WIP: Build separate Python 3.9 image](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/analyzers/gemnasium-python/-/merge_requests/101) for PoC

   1. Fix broken [python-3.9-pip-qa](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/tests/python-pip/-/pipelines/300091302) test

1. Add build job similar to [`build tmp image`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/blob/master/includes-dev/analyzer.yml#L60), and that sets PYTHON_VERSION (Docker build argument) and TMP_IMAGE (to avoid collision)

   See [Add build tmp python image job](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/security-products/ci-templates/-/commit/be813316fc585f66cab058015db9909f7963efce) for details

1. Add "tag jobs" to publish the temporary images
1. Test new `python-3.9` image with:
   - a customer who uses python 3.9
   - a customer who uses python 3.7

title: Convert ci_builds_runner_session.build_id to bigint - Step 2: Finalize background migrations and swap columns
description:
With gitlab-org/gitlab#328444 we have started the process of converting the foreign key from `ci_builds_runner_session` that references `ci_builds` (`ci_builds_runner_session.build_id`) to `bigint` (`int8`).

In this issue we'll address the second step of the process:

* Clean up the background migrations
* Drop the `DEFAULT 0` from the `build_id_convert_to_bigint` column
* Concurrently add any secondary indexes that include the `build_id` column

  ```
  "index_ci_builds_runner_session_on_build_id" UNIQUE, btree (build_id)
  ```
* Single Transaction: Drop old FK, define new FK (as invalid), swap columns, validate FK

epic.title: Address the Primary Key Overflow risk for the ci_builds table

title: Convert ci_builds_runner_session.build_id to bigint - Step 1: Add new columns and sync data
description:
The `ci_builds_runner_session` table is one of the CI tables that reference [ci_builds](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/325618), which we want to convert as it's [Primary Key is at risk of overflowing](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4785).

```sql
gitlabhq_production=> \d ci_builds_runner_session
                                     Table "public.ci_builds_runner_session"
    Column     |       Type        | Collation | Nullable |                       Default
---------------+-------------------+-----------+----------+------------------------------------------------------
 ...
 build_id      | integer           |           | not null |
 ...
Indexes:
    "index_ci_builds_runner_session_on_build_id" UNIQUE, btree (build_id)
Foreign-key constraints:
    "fk_rails_70707857d3" FOREIGN KEY (build_id) REFERENCES ci_builds(id) ON DELETE CASCADE
```

The first step to address the problem is to create a new column of type `bigint`, load all the data by using background jobs from the current `build_id` column to it and keep them in sync with a trigger.

The overall process for the `ci_builds_runner_session` table will be as follows:

* Create a new column `ci_builds_runner_session.build_id_convert_to_bigint` for the Foreign Key that references `ci_builds`, with `bigint NOT NULL DEFAULT 0`
* Install sync triggers to keep the new columns updated while new records are inserted or existing ones are updated or deleted.
* Start background jobs that will batch through the whole table and copy the `build_id` values to the new column.

We'll follow with a cleanup migration in the next milestone than the one that the aforementioned migrations are deployed, which will add the necessary indexes, swap the PK (and its sequence) and the FKs and finally drop the old columns.

title: Convert ci_build_trace_sections.build_id to bigint - Step 2: Finalize background migrations and swap columns
description:
~"won't do" - we'll drop the whole table! See https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328433#note_627463448


With gitlab-org/gitlab#328432 we have started the process of converting the foreign key from `ci_build_trace_sections` that references `ci_builds` (`ci_build_trace_sections.build_id`) to `bigint` (`int8`).

In this issue we'll address the second step of the process:

* Clean up the background migrations
* Drop the `DEFAULT 0` from the `build_id_convert_to_bigint` column
* Concurrently add a Unique index for the PK (`"ci_build_trace_sections_pkey" PRIMARY KEY, btree (build_id, section_name_id)`)
* There are no secondary indexes that include the `build_id` column so no additional action is required on this step
* Single Transaction: Drop old PK, define new PK using the unique index, swap sequence, swap columns
* Single Transaction: Drop old FK, define new FK (as invalid), validate FK

epic.title: Address the Primary Key Overflow risk for the ci_builds table

title: Convert ci_build_trace_sections.build_id to bigint - Step 1: Add new columns and sync data
description:
The `ci_build_trace_sections` table is the largest CI table that references [ci_builds](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/325618), with \~5.4 Billion records. As the Primary Key of `ci_builds` [is at risk of overflowing](https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/4785), we have to convert both to `bigint`.

The first step to address the problem is to create a new column of type `bigint`, load all the data by using background jobs from the current `build_id` column to it and keep them in sync with a trigger.

The overall process for the `ci_build_trace_sections` table will be as follows:

* Create a new column `ci_build_trace_sections.build_id_convert_to_bigint` for the Foreign Key that references `ci_builds` (also part of the Primary Key), with `bigint NOT NULL DEFAULT 0`
* Install sync triggers to keep the new columns updated while new records are inserted or existing ones are updated or deleted.
* Start background jobs that will batch through the whole table and copy the `build_id` values to the new column.

Care should be taken on how we are going to batch through `ci_build_trace_sections` as it has a composite key defined:

```
"ci_build_trace_sections_pkey" PRIMARY KEY, btree (build_id, section_name_id)
```

We'll follow with a cleanup migration in the next milestone than the one that the aforementioned migrations are deployed, which will add the necessary indexes, swap the PK (and its sequence) and the FKs and finally drop the old columns.

title: MVC: Illustrate translation coverage in language selection dropdown
description:
As a first step :footprints: toward https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/18923, we can make the translation levels hardcoded and manually update them on a cadence.

title: Something went wrong while fetching Epics
description:
### Summary When viewing epics on the roadmap at `groups/my_group_name/-/roadmap`, the page will produce an error that says "Something went wrong while fetching epics" when attempting to scroll the page. This happens on multiple groups for the same user. Interestingly, it seems to be replicated in only `Chrome (Version 89.0.4389.90 (Official Build) (64-bit)` but it does not happen in `Firefox (Version 87.0 (64-bit))` Would be interested in developer feedback if further debugging is needed. ### Steps to reproduce Not able to replicate outside of a specific customer example 1. Go to a group or subgroup 1. Go to Epics > Roadmaps 1. Try to scroll the page ### Example Project Please see [ZD Ticket](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/206980) with attached .har ### What is the current *bug* behavior? Scrolling/navigating on the Epics > Roadmap page shows a "Something went wrong while fetching Epics" error without any indicate on why it's unable to load. ### What is the expected *correct* behavior? A user should be able to load Epics > Roadmap or know why epics are unable to be loaded ### Relevant logs and/or screenshots - https://log.gprd.gitlab.net/goto/0cea8ee2d60227a50ef95886dd757091 (internal) - Unable to find any exceptions in kibana, or sentry - Unable to replicate via impersonation - Network .har is attached to the [ZD Ticket](https://gitlab.zendesk.com/agent/tickets/206980), no obvious requests being blocked ### Output of checks This happens on GitLab.com 13.11.0-pre ef1acea72ef #### Results of GitLab environment info
Expand for output related to GitLab environment info 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:env:info`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:env:info RAILS_ENV=production`)
#### Results of GitLab application Check
Expand for output related to the GitLab application check 

(For installations with omnibus-gitlab package run and paste the output of:
`sudo gitlab-rake gitlab:check SANITIZE=true`)

(For installations from source run and paste the output of:
`sudo -u git -H bundle exec rake gitlab:check RAILS_ENV=production SANITIZE=true`)

(we will only investigate if the tests are passing)
### Possible fixes
