title: Investigate and summarise past database incident root causes
description:
In https://gitlab.com/groups/gitlab-org/-/epics/5759 we are looking in various approaches to sharding the GitLab.com database, as well as other potential solutions to allow us to scale and provide a more reliable service.

As part of this, I'll take a look at past database incidents and summarise their root causes, affected tables, etc. This should help us better understand what patterns of incidents we are dealing with, instead of basing decisions on either tribal knowledge or something we _think_ may be the problem.

title: VSA: Stage ID mismatch in specs
description:
It appears that the JSON fixtures we are using in our [VSA mock data](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/spec/frontend/analytics/cycle_analytics/mock_data.js) generate stages with numeric IDs.
However, we are using [alphabetic stage ids](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/spec/frontend/analytics/cycle_analytics/mock_data.js#L111) in our specs.

This causes issues when we are doing lookups, like in [transformStagesForPathNavigation](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/analytics/cycle_analytics/utils.js#L440) as this won't return any findings.

As a result, stage data in our specs doesn't have metrics but `undefined` instead.

* We should ensure we update related specs, such as https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/59606#note_556254202

title: Missing data on CiJob Type
description:
I've found some missing data from the `CiJob` Type that we will need to build out the new table correctly.

Here is what the current HAML implementation does that we will need to be able to recreate with GraphQL.

### For Labels

1. We display a `triggered` label based on
`job.try(:trigger_request)`

2. We display a `manual` label based on 
`job.action?`

We actually can display this in a hacky not preferred way right now by determining if the job is manual by diving into the `detailedStatus`. But it's preferable to have a boolean. 

Check out https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/views/projects/ci/builds/_build.html.haml#L48-55 block to get a good idea of the implementation. We have `allowFailure` in GraphQL already which is nice :smile_cat: 

### For tag

Currently we display a label icon if the job is from a tag and a fork icon if not. See code https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/master/app/views/projects/ci/builds/_build.html.haml#L25

We need a way in GraphQL to do this logic. A returned boolean that says this job is from a tag.


### Ideal Query

Naming of course can be tweaked as seen fit.

```graphql
project(fullPath: $fullPath) {
  jobs {
    nodes {
      triggered
      tag
      action
    }
  }
}
```

title: Stored XSS in the Jira issue detail pages
description:
**[HackerOne report #1132083](https://hackerone.com/reports/1132083)** by `thornguyen` on 2021-03-22, assigned to @ngeorge1:

[Report](#report) | [Attachments](#attachments) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

#####  Summary

I've found a stored XSS vulnerability in the Jira issue detail pages by exploiting Jira integration. Also, I was able to bypass CSP and gain full javascript execution under gitlab.com context.

#####  Steps to reproduce  
1. Create a **Mock API** that response this payload ![payload.json]([REDACTED]) when there are requests to path ```/rest/api/2/issue/POC?expand=renderedFields```.  You can use https://beeceptor.com/ like my POC video.

2. In a GitLab project that has premium / ultimate license , go to **Settings -> Integrations -> Jira**:  
- Tick active at the **Enable integration** section  
- Input any URL at **Web URL** field  
- Input the mock API created in Step 1 to the **Jira API URL** field  
- Click **Save changes**

3. Now go to https://gitlab.com/[YOUR_ORGANIZATION]/[YOUR_PROJECT]/-/integrations/jira/issues/POC  and you will see a popup.

#####  Impact  
Stored-XSS allow attackers to perform arbitrary actions on behalf of victims at client side. And since the JIRA issue detail pages can be made public, this impact a considerable number of GitLab users and visitors.

#####  Examples

- [REDACTED] (tested in Chrome and Firefox)

#####  What is the current *bug* behavior?

GitLab doesn't sanitize the *key* field in the JSON response from Jira API so it leads to stored XSS at the Jira issue detail pages.

[REDACTED]
#####  POC Video

![REDACTED]
#####  What is the expected *correct* behavior?

GitLab should sanitize *key* field in the JSON response from Jira API before output to browser.

#####  Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

####  Impact

Stored-XSS allow attackers to perform arbitrary actions on behalf of victims at client side. And since the JIRA issue detail pages can be made public, this impact a considerable number of GitLab users and visitors.

title: Create Card with Variants for Security Config Page
description:
<!--
Implementation issues are used break-up a large piece of work into small, discrete tasks that can
move independently through the build workflow steps. They're typically used to populate a Feature
Epic. Once created, an implementation issue is usually refined in order to populate and review the
implementation plan and weight.
Example workflow: https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/engineering/development/threat-management/planning/diagram.html#plan
-->

## Why are we doing this work
<!--
A brief explanation of the why, not the what or how. Assume the reader doesn't know the
background and won't have time to dig-up information from comment threads.
-->

For the redesign of the Security Config Page [tracked here](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326926/),
we will need to build a [card component](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326926/designs/CONFIG_project-security_testing-tool_states-framework.png) with various states as described in the design.



## Relevant links
<!--
Information that the developer might need to refer to when implementing the issue.

- [Design Issue](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/326926)

title: Geo: Deduplicate more jobs using `:until_executed` strategy
description:
https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/328057#note_555466921

>>>
> Instead of being deduplicated at the time of work being picked up, maybe switch to not scheduling an item for work if one is already being processed?

Good idea :thumbsup:

Independent of exclusive leases, the Scalability team implemented job deduplication generically. These jobs shouldn't be getting enqueued if any are already enqueued with the same job arguments: https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/doc/development/sidekiq_style_guide.md#deduplication. So the problem should be somewhat limited already.

#### Proposal: Deduplicate until executed

But actually this is a perfect case for changing this worker from the default job deduplication strategy (`:until_executing`) to instead use `:until_executed`. This will throw out jobs if another one with duplicate args is currently running. I think we could even remove the exclusive lease code. This should help a bit. I'll open an issue.
>>>

(Referring to `Geo::RepositoryVerification::Primary::ShardWorker`)

There is no reason to schedule one of these workers if one with the same args is already running. Further, this is labelled a bug because in the above issue it contributes to poor/buggy performance.

## Proposal

- Add `deduplicate :until_executed` to `Geo::RepositoryVerification::Primary::ShardWorker`
  - ~~Remove `try_obtain_lease` block and any code it depends on that is no longer needed.~~ It doesn't matter much if we do this now or later, so let's avoid touching everything, while reaping the benefits of the easy change.
- Open similar issues for any others you notice could benefit from this => I modified the superclasses in https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/merge_requests/59799 so many similar workers will benefit

title: Update to Jira Connect App qsh verification
description:
Atlassian is introducing a breaking change to address a security vulnerability:

[Action required: Atlassian Connect vulnerability allows bypass of app qsh verification via context JWTs](https://community.developer.atlassian.com/t/action-required-atlassian-connect-vulnerability-allows-bypass-of-app-qsh-verification-via-context-jwts/47072?utm_source=alert-email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=vulnerability-api-change_EML-10294&jobid=105040724&subid=1590526977)

It looks like our app is affected because we are using JWT authentication. We do [verify the qsh claim](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/blob/v13.10.3-ee/app/controllers/jira_connect/application_controller.rb#L22-29) but we should still follow the steps described [here](https://community.developer.atlassian.com/t/action-required-atlassian-connect-vulnerability-allows-bypass-of-app-qsh-verification-via-context-jwts/47072?utm_source=alert-email&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=vulnerability-api-change_EML-10294&jobid=105040724&subid=1590526977#running-a-custom-implementation). 

Setting ~"priority::2" because the change will be enforced by Jun 7, 2021.

title: Migrate pipeline code quality report to GraphQL
description:
## Release notes

It is possible for you to run linters and scanners in addition to the one included with the GitLab Code Quality Template. If you generate that data in another job though only the last CodeQuality report will be used by GitLab's Code Quality features so you are missing out on issues detected by all the scans.

Now the Full Code Quality report supports reading multiple reports and displaying data from all of them. This means you can get a better view of quality issues in your code and fix them earlier in the development process.

## Summary

In order to move forward quickly with future iterations of the pipeline code quality report tab, it is important that we lay a proper foundation by moving this report to GraphQL.

## Improvements

- Allow for quicker iterations between ~frontend and ~backend 
- Take advantage of the caching we already have on that page from other components using GraphQL

## Risks

We could break the page temporarily. However, we can mitigate this possibility by using a feature flag to enable/disable this migration.

## Involved components

~frontend 

- [ ] [`ee/app/assets/javascripts/pages/projects/pipelines/show/codequality_report.js`](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/blob/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/pages/projects/pipelines/show/codequality_report.js)
- [ ] [everything in the `ee/app/assets/javascripts/codequality_report` folder](https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/tree/master/ee/app/assets/javascripts/codequality_report)
- [ ] Implement ~feature using new `GraphQL API`
- [ ] Remove custom logic for sorting degradations
- [ ] Add a note to [the code quality report documentation](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/user/project/merge_requests/code_quality.html#code-quality-reports) about supporting multiple reports as of this release version.

~backend
### Implementation Plan :writing_hand: 

| Step | MR(s)/Issue(s) | Status |
| --------------------------------------------------------- | ------ | ------------------------ | 
| ~backend Introduce a new `CodeQualityReportType` in GraphQL (EE)   | !61383 | ~"workflow::production"  |
| ~backend Filter degradations by severity                           | !62710 | ~"workflow::production"  |
| ~frontend MVC to get the GraphQL data into the same spot where the REST data was | !69917 | ~"workflow::production" |
| ~frontend Improve the GraphQL ~UX to match what we had in the REST version, set up [fixtures](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/development/testing_guide/frontend_testing.html#graphql-query-fixtures) to use in the frontend specs instead of mock data | !72036 | ~"workflow::in review"  |
| Perform the feature flag rollout | https://gitlab.com/gitlab-org/gitlab/-/issues/340525 |
| ~frontend Remove the feature flag, clean up dead code |  |  |
| ~documentation Add a note about support for multiple reports (could be combined with feature flag removal) |  |  |
| ~backend Remove existing `REST API`                                |  | ~blocked (waiting to implement ~frontend first) |

title: Demoted user (Developer or above demoted to Guest) can view new activity in MRs created by them via RSS feed
description:
**[HackerOne report #1130777](https://hackerone.com/reports/1130777)** by `jimeno` on 2021-03-19, assigned to @dcouture:

[Report](#report) | [Attachments](#attachments) | [How To Reproduce](#how-to-reproduce)

## Report

#####  Summary

Demoted user (Developer or above demoted to Guest) can view new activity in MRs created by them via RSS feed. This is very similar to #962604.

#####  Steps to reproduce

1. As victim, create a private project with at least one file.

    ![create_private_project.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/0f4fb524-e8eb-41d8-9fa3-f15e4b42e36d/create_private_project.png)

2. Invite attacker user with Developer role.

    ![invited_developer.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/0642c2f9-3979-4a71-be1d-8fbf14e75214/invited_developer.png)

3. As attacker, create a MR.

    ![random_change_by_attacker.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/f3c4764c-7534-4b1c-a101-215585484010/random_change_by_attacker.png)

    ![test_mr_by_attacker.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/9ae540d1-041a-4484-b17a-2e2d88c5a5b9/test_mr_by_attacker.png)

4. As victim, demote the attacker user to Guest role.

    ![demoted_to_guest.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/d96477f1-eadf-4a15-82b5-1386cfe9ebe7/demoted_to_guest.png)

5. As victim, add a random activity to the MR. For simplicity, just post a comment and then approve the MR.

    ![admin_comments_and_approves_after_demoting.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/7e48ad6b-fca0-4327-b53f-ea9ef94ca6ea/admin_comments_and_approves_after_demoting.png)

5. As attacker, browse to the RSS feed of the project (`https://gitlab.com/victimuser/projectname.atom`).  
6. Verify you can see the MR is approved and the comment contents.

    ![guest_can_see_activity_via_rss_feed.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/5d169575-1d6a-4348-8501-9dd3673760b9/guest_can_see_activity_via_rss_feed.png)

7. Verify you can't browse to the MR.

    ![guest_cannot_see_their_mr.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/f030b312-a5f9-426a-93ab-e53b77735cf5/guest_cannot_see_their_mr.png)


#####  Impact

Demoted user (Developer or above to Guest) can view new activity in MRs created by them via RSS feed.

#####  Examples

Please, find the attached exported project.  [2021-03-19_16-10-667_naaytesting2_h1demoterssproof_export.tar.gz](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/cab7cac9-00ee-41c0-b32d-1c24de0f9ff7/2021-03-19_16-10-667_naaytesting2_h1demoterssproof_export.tar.gz)

#####  What is the current *bug* behavior?

New MR activity is shown to the demoted user via RSS feed.

#####  What is the expected *correct* behavior?

No new MR activity (or no MR activity at all) is shown to the demoted user via RSS feed.

#####  Relevant logs and/or screenshots

N/A

#####  Output of checks

This bug happens on GitLab.com

######  Results of GitLab environment info

N/A

####  Impact

Demoted user (Developer or above to Guest) can view new activity in MRs created by them via RSS feed.

## Attachments

**Warning:** Attachments received through HackerOne, please exercise caution!

* [2021-03-19_16-10-667_naaytesting2_h1demoterssproof_export.tar.gz](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/cab7cac9-00ee-41c0-b32d-1c24de0f9ff7/2021-03-19_16-10-667_naaytesting2_h1demoterssproof_export.tar.gz)
* [admin_comments_and_approves_after_demoting.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/7e48ad6b-fca0-4327-b53f-ea9ef94ca6ea/admin_comments_and_approves_after_demoting.png)
* [guest_can_see_activity_via_rss_feed.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/5d169575-1d6a-4348-8501-9dd3673760b9/guest_can_see_activity_via_rss_feed.png)
* [guest_cannot_see_their_mr.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/f030b312-a5f9-426a-93ab-e53b77735cf5/guest_cannot_see_their_mr.png)
* [demoted_to_guest.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/d96477f1-eadf-4a15-82b5-1386cfe9ebe7/demoted_to_guest.png)
* [test_mr_by_attacker.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/9ae540d1-041a-4484-b17a-2e2d88c5a5b9/test_mr_by_attacker.png)
* [random_change_by_attacker.png](https://h1.sec.gitlab.net/a/f3c4764c-7534-4b1c-a101-215585484010/random_change_by_attacker.png)

### Release notes


### Problem to solve

Filter issues by issue_type in issue lists. Incidents are now a type of issue and it is currently impossible to filter issues by type. Users need this for triage.

### Intended users

* [Devon (DevOps Engineer)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#devon-devops-engineer)
* [Allison (Application Ops)](https://about.gitlab.com/handbook/marketing/product-marketing/roles-personas/#allison-application-ops)


### User experience goal

### Proposal

Enable filtering by issue type in issue lists. Add a new row called "Type" which lets you filter by the type of Issue on an Issue List.

### Further details

This work supports the [incident management direction](https://about.gitlab.com/direction/monitor/debugging_and_health/incident_management/).

### Permissions and Security
